title: Contributing
text: Awesome reading . GitHub follows Contributor Covenant Code Conduct. questions, can create Issue Code changes go via Pull Requests

title: Contributing
text: New use cases welcome. can : Add Issue Send @richelbilderbeek email (@richelbilderbeek make Issue )

title: Contributing
text: tracerer part babette package suite, consists five packages. determine package best suited contribution: want contribute creation BEAST2 XML input file, go beautier. want contribute BEAST2 run, go beautier. want contribute regarding BEAST2 package management, go mauricer want contribute overarching idea, go babette want contribute BEAST2 output parsed, right spot :-)

title: Contributing
text: Submitted code follow quality guidelines: tests pass cleanly/silently Code coverage 95% Coding style follow default style lintr checked Travis CI submitting Pull Request. Emails code accepted.

title: Contributing
text: Awesome. options: Add Issue, test fails Submit Pull Request, test added tests/testthat folder Send @richelbilderbeek email (@richelbilderbeek make Issue ) Pull Requests follow guidelines ‘Submitting code’.

title: Contributing
text: master branch always build successfully development branch developers

title: Contributing
text: get started working tracerer : Development done develop branch. download checkout develop branch, first go tracerer folder (cd tracerer), : workflow common git workflow:
code: git clone https://github.com/ropensci/tracerer git checkout develop git pull git add --all :/ git commit -m "Did something awesome" git push

title: Authors and Citation
text: Richèl J.C. Bilderbeek. Author, maintainer. Joëlle Barido-Sottani. Reviewer.            Joëlle reviewed package rOpenSci, see https://github.com/ropensci/onboarding/issues/209 David Winter. Reviewer.            David reviewed package rOpenSci, see https://github.com/ropensci/onboarding/issues/209

title: Authors and Citation
text: Bilderbeek RJ, Etienne RS (2008). “babette: BEAUti 2, BEAST 2 Tracer R.” Methods Ecology Evolution. https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.13032.
code: @Article{,   author = {Richèl JC Bilderbeek and Rampal S Etienne},   title = {babette: BEAUti 2, BEAST 2 and Tracer for R},   journal = {Methods in Ecology and Evolution},   year = {2008},   url = {https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.13032}, }

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: interest fostering open welcoming environment, contributors maintainers pledge making participation project community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, disability, ethnicity, gender identity expression, level experience, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes creating positive environment include: Using welcoming inclusive language respectful differing viewpoints experiences Gracefully accepting constructive criticism Focusing best community Showing empathy towards community members Examples unacceptable behavior participants include: use sexualized language imagery unwelcome sexual attention advances Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical electronic address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Project maintainers responsible clarifying standards acceptable behavior expected take appropriate fair corrective action response instances unacceptable behavior. Project maintainers right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, ban temporarily permanently contributor behaviors deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within project spaces public spaces individual representing project community. Examples representing project community include using official project e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event. Representation project may defined clarified project maintainers.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported contacting project team richel@richelbilderbeek.nl. complaints reviewed investigated result response deemed necessary appropriate circumstances. project team obligated maintain confidentiality regarding reporter incident. details specific enforcement policies may posted separately. Project maintainers follow enforce Code Conduct good faith may face temporary permanent repercussions determined members project’s leadership.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 1.4, available http://contributor-covenant.org/version/1/4

title: FAQ
text: Initially, logo low-tech remake Tracer, game Overwatch Blizzard. prevent problems Blizzard, different logo picked. current logo shows ant, animal leaves trace pheromones. drawn Jose Scholte, kindly allowed work used free, attribution.

title: Tracer from R
text: tracerer, ‘Tracer R’ R package work BEAST2 output files. tracerer logo tracerer part babette package suite: beautier creates BEAST2 input (.xml) files. beastier runs BEAST2 mauricer: install BEAST2 packages tracerer pastes BEAST2 output (.log, .trees, etc) files. Related R packages: lumier: Shiny app help create function call needed BEASTmasteR: tip-dating using fossils dated terminal taxa RBeast: misc things tracerer_on_windows: verifies tracerer builds Windows

title: Tracer from R
code: library(tracerer)  # Obtain an example log file its name filename <- get_tracerer_path("beast2_example_output.log")  # Parse that log file beast_log_full <- parse_beast_tracelog_file(filename)  # Remove the burn-in beast_log <- remove_burn_ins(   beast_log_full,   burn_in_fraction = 0.1 )  # Calculates the effective sample sizes of all parameter estimates esses <- calc_esses(beast_log, sample_interval = 1000)

title:
Calculate the Highest Probability Density of an MCMC trace that
  has its burn-in removed — calc_hpd_interval
text: original Java version algorithm J. Heled,   ported R adapted Richèl J.C. Bilderbeek

title:
Calculate the Highest Probability Density of an MCMC trace that
  has its burn-in removed — calc_hpd_interval
code: estimates <- parse_beast_tracelog_file(   get_tracerer_path("beast2_example_output.log") ) tree_height_trace <- remove_burn_in(   estimates$TreeHeight,   burn_in_fraction = 0.1 )  # Values will be 0.453 and 1.816 calc_hpd_interval(tree_height_trace, proportion = 0.95) #> [1] 0.4529637 1.8159958

what: Calculates the Effective Sample Sizes of one estimated variable's trace. — calc_summary_stats
title: Calculates the Effective Sample Sizes of one estimated variable's trace. — calc_summary_stats
text: Calculates Effective Sample Sizes one estimated variable's trace.

title: Calculates the Effective Sample Sizes of one estimated variable's trace. — calc_summary_stats
Calculates the Effective Sample Sizes of one estimated variable's trace. — calc_summary_stats
text: traces one traces, supplies either, (1) numeric vector , (2) data frame numeric values. sample_interval interval (number state transitions samples) MCMC run produced trace. Using different sample_interval actually used sampling interval result bogus return values.

title: Calculates the Effective Sample Sizes of one estimated variable's trace. — calc_summary_stats
text: summary statistics traces. one numeric vector supplied, list returned elements listed . traces supplied data frame, data frame returned elements listed column names. elements : mean: mean stderr_mean: standard error mean stdev: standard deviation variance: variance mode: mode geom_mean: geometric mean hpd_interval_low:     lower bound 95% highest posterior density hpd_interval_high:     upper bound 95% highest posterior density act: auto correlation time ess: effective sample size

title: Calculates the Effective Sample Sizes of one estimated variable's trace. — calc_summary_stats
text: function assumes burn-removed.   Use remove_burn_in (vector)   remove_burn_ins (data frame) remove   burn-.

title: Calculates the Effective Sample Sizes of one estimated variable's trace. — calc_summary_stats
Calculates the Effective Sample Sizes of one estimated variable's trace. — calc_summary_stats
code: estimates_all <- parse_beast_tracelog_file(   get_tracerer_path("beast2_example_output.log") ) estimates <- remove_burn_ins(estimates_all, burn_in_fraction = 0.1)  # From a single variable's trace calc_summary_stats(   estimates$posterior,   sample_interval = 1000 ) #>        mean stderr_mean    stdev variance    median mode geom_mean #> 1 -70.58394   0.5044887 1.681629 2.827876 -69.87976  n/a       n/a #>   hpd_interval_low hpd_interval_high  act ess #> 1        -74.15268         -68.68523 1000  10  # From all variables' traces calc_summary_stats(   estimates,   sample_interval = 1000 ) #>                           mean stderr_mean     stdev   variance      median #> posterior          -70.5839432  0.50448873 1.6816291 2.82787643 -69.8797613 #> likelihood         -60.1725009  0.39642076 1.3214025 1.74610467 -60.0504225 #> prior              -10.4114423  0.54245052 1.8081684 3.26947291 -10.5950270 #> treeLikelihood     -60.1725009  0.39642076 1.3214025 1.74610467 -60.0504225 #> TreeHeight           0.9744748  0.14399367 0.3916244 0.15336965   0.8755907 #> BirthDeath          -3.5036870  0.54245052 1.8081684 3.26947291  -3.6872718 #> birthRate2           1.4470488  0.21344112 0.6713951 0.45077144   1.4118781 #> relativeDeathRate2   0.4937568  0.06502354 0.1709096 0.02921009   0.4480670 #>                    mode         geom_mean hpd_interval_low hpd_interval_high #> posterior           n/a               n/a      -74.1526820       -68.6852294 #> likelihood          n/a               n/a      -62.4090389       -58.7371284 #> prior               n/a               n/a      -14.1703653        -7.2820933 #> treeLikelihood      n/a               n/a      -62.4090389       -58.7371284 #> TreeHeight          n/a  0.91041547166058        0.4529637         1.8159958 #> BirthDeath          n/a               n/a       -7.2626100        -0.3743380 #> birthRate2          n/a  1.28823302868404        0.3909076         2.8041208 #> relativeDeathRate2  n/a 0.466468860930895        0.2496224         0.7107459 #>                         act       ess #> posterior          1000.000 10.000000 #> likelihood         1000.000 10.000000 #> prior              1000.000 10.000000 #> treeLikelihood     1000.000 10.000000 #> TreeHeight         1502.121  6.657254 #> BirthDeath         1000.000 10.000000 #> birthRate2         1122.942  8.905181 #> relativeDeathRate2 1608.296  6.217762

what: tracerer: A package to parse BEAST2 output files. — tracerer-package
title: tracerer: A package to parse BEAST2 output files. — tracerer-package
